bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: Telegrams to the War Department report individual deaths, including those from yellow fever, from June 10 to June 20, 1900. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report of deaths, June 1900
div1.p:
328173 A.G.O.
A.
CB
Filed with 326817 A.G.O.

Report of deaths June 10,
to June 20, 1900.

Major Frank H. Edmunds,
1st Inf. June 18, 1900, yellow
fever.

Pvt. William K. Clewer,
Troop E. 7th Cav. June 10, 1900,
abcess of liver with peritonitis.

Pvt. James E. Levy, Troop A.
2d Cav. June 15, 1900, dysentery.

Pvt. Dell Winteringham,
Troop B. 2d Cav. June 19, 1900,
yellow fever.

CABLE MESSAGE.
THE WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY.

All CABLE MESSAGES received for transmission must be written on the Message Blanks provided by this Company for that purpose, under and subject to
the conditions printed thereon, and on the back hereof, which conditions have been agreed to by the sender of the following message.
THOS. T. ECKERT, President and General Manager.

TWO AMERICAN CABLES FROM NEW YORK TO GREAT BRITAIN.
CONNECTS ALSO WITH FIVE ANGLO-AMERICAN AND ONE DIRECT U.S. ATLANTIC CABLES.
DIRECT CABLE COMMUNICATION WITH GERMANY AND FRANCE.
CABLE CONNECTION WITH CUBA, WEST INDIES, MEXICO AND CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA.
MESSAGES SENT TO, AND RECEIVED FROM, ALL PARTS OF THE WORLD.

All Offices (21,000) of the Western Union Telegraph Company and its Connections.
120

LONDON:
No. 21 Royal Exchange, E.C.
No. 109 Fenchurch Street, E.C.

LIVERPOOL: No. 8 Rumford Street.
GLASGOW: No. 29 Gordon St. and No. 4 Waterloo St.
BRISTOL: Backhall Chambers.

Copies supplied June 21, 1900
Sec. War Col. Ward.
Adj. Gen. Col. Carter.
✓ Hdqrs. Army Mr. Heitman.
Inspc. Gen. Mr. Wilson.
✓ Q. M. G. Mr. Staffard
Com. Gen. Subs.
✓ Surgeon Gen.
✓ Paymstr. Gen. and Depot Paymastr
Chf. Ordnance
✓ Bulletin.

Havana
56
NOTED: RETURNS, A. G. O.,
9

Adjutant General's
OFFICE.
JUN 21 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
[unclear]

Death report tenth to twentieth Columbia Barracks Major
Frank H. Edmunds 1st infantry yellow fever June eighteenth Pinardelrio
Private William K Clewer E. Seventh cavalry abcess of liver with peritoni-
tis June tenth Matanzas Private James E. Levy A. Second cavalry disintery
June fifteenth SantaClara Private Deltl Winteringham B. Second cavalry
yellow fever nineteenth.
